headline: Air travel recovery to take 'several days' post-shutdown: Delta CEO
summary: The government shutdown is over, but that doesn't mean air travel will return to normal right away. Delta Air Lines (DAL) CEO Ed Bastian says it's going to take "several days" for everything to get back up and running again. Be sure to check out the full Yahoo Finance Invest interview with Delta CEO Ed Bastian.  For full interviews, highlights, and key insights, check out more from Yahoo Finance Invest.

headline: Is Swift Progress on Government Reopening Changing the Outlook for Delta Air Lines (DAL)?
summary: Delta Air Lines recently experienced widespread operational disruptions due to a U.S. government shutdown, but the carrier anticipates a swift recovery as the Senate passed a deal to reopen the government and resolve air traffic constraints. This renewed optimism is supported by CEO Ed Bastian expressing confidence in a strong fourth quarter and holiday season, alongside recognition of the airline’s resilience as it marks its 100th anniversary and embraces new technology for improved cargo...

headline: Delta Recognized by Frost & Sullivan as "Company of the Year" for Integrated Energy Solutions in Europe
summary: Delta, a global leader in power management and smart green solutions, today announced it has been named the 2025 Company of the Year in the European Integrated Energy Solutions industry by Frost & Sullivan. This top honor recognizes Delta for its innovation capabilities, market-leading performance, and outstanding customer service, solidifying its position as a key enabler for Europe's energy transition.

headline: Shutdown’s End Will Kick Off Long Process of Rebooting US Government
summary: Delayed environmental permits, workplace inspections and contracting activities have stacked up across federal agencies.  The work of re-opening the government couldn’t officially launch until the funding bill has passed both chambers of Congress and had President Donald Trump’s signature late Wednesday.  The White House’s budget office directed all federal employees who had been furloughed during the shutdown to return to work on Thursday.

raw.headline: Shutdown’s End Will Kick Off Long Process of Rebooting US Government
raw.summary: Delayed environmental permits, workplace inspections and contracting activities have stacked up across federal agencies.  The work of re-opening the government couldn’t officially launch until the funding bill has passed both chambers of Congress and had President Donald Trump’s signature late Wednesday.  The White House’s budget office directed all federal employees who had been furloughed during the shutdown to return to work on Thursday.

headline: Record US Government Shutdown Ends as Trump Signs Spending Bill
summary: Trump’s signature means the government can begin to resume normal operations, with federal workers expected back on the job starting Thursday.  Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy told reporters earlier Wednesday he anticipated it could take as long as a week to start lifting flight restrictions at major airports.  The Congressional Budget Office last month projected a six-week government closure would lower real gross domestic product growth in the current quarter by 1.5 percentage points.
